sentence.text: Cloning and characterization of two evolutionarily conserved subunits (_________ and ________) of human ______ and their involvement in functional interactions with TFIIIB and RNA polymerase III
Identification of residues in the ______________________________ that contact the MCP-1 receptor, ____
The receptor binding site of _____ also is significantly different from the binding sites of ______ and ____, providing insight into the issue of receptor specificity
It was previously shown that the N-terminus of ____ is critical for binding _____
To identify the regions of _____ that contact its receptor, ____, we substituted all surface-exposed residues with alanine
We tested this point by cotransfecting CHO cells with the genes encoding F beta alpha and the _______ subunit or the _____________ and ________ monomer

The formation of a functional single chain/subunit complex was not restricted to the FSH single chain/_______ subunit since CG single chain interacts with the monomeric ________ subunit and exhibits FSH activity

This is relevant for the case of LH and FSH, because both are synthesized in the same cell (i.e., pituitary gonadotrophs) and several of the alpha subunit sequences required for association with either the _______ or ________ subunits are different
Previously, we showed that the _______ or ________ subunit genes can be genetically fused to the alpha gene to produce biologically active single chains, _____________ and F beta alpha, respectively
_____________ activates _____________________________, which inhibits apoptosis in human prostate cancer cell lines
RESULTS: Tyrosine phosphorylation of p85 is upregulated by ____ in both LNCaP and ____
____ promotes coprecipitation of p85 with _____, the signal-transducing component of the _____________
In solution, FGFR4ed formed complexes with __________________ and _________________, both in the presence and absence of heparin
Immobilized _____ also bound _____ besides _____ and _____
___________ regulates beta-2 integrin-mediated adhesion through both ARF-GEF function and interaction with _____
Here we provide evidence of how ___________, an integrin-binding protein and guanine-nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) for ___ GTPases, regulates cell adhesion

Mutational analyses of the beta-2 cytoplasmic domain revealed that the adhesive function of _____ depends on its interaction with ___________, unless the integrin is activated by exogenous divalent cations
Secondly, ___________ induces expression of an extracellular activation epitope of _____, and the exchange factor function is not essential for this activity
In contrast, LFA-1-mediated cell adhesion and spreading on intercellular cell adhesion molecule 1 is strongly inhibited by a ___________ mutant, which fails to catalyze ___ GDP-GTP exchange in vitro
Thus, ___________ is involved in the activation of _____, most probably through direct interaction with the integrin, and induces cell spreading by its ARF-GEF activity
Suppression of rat thromboxane synthase gene transcription by ________________________________________________ in macrophages via an interaction with ____

Deletion analysis showed that the element responsible for the PPARgamma effect is located in a region containing the nuclear factor E2 (_____)/____ site (-98/-88), which was indicated to be the major promoter of the TXS gene

By electrophoretic mobility shift assay using the _____/____ site and nuclear extracts from macrophages, we observed a specific protein-DNA complex formation, which was inhibited by a specific antibody against the transcription factor ____ (______________________)
Finally, a direct interaction between PPARgamma and ____ was confirmed by _________________________ pull-down assay

By constructing deletion mutants, we identified that amino acid residues 229-309 of Akt were involved in the binding to _____ and amino acid residues 327-340 of _________ were involved in the binding to Akt
Here, we cloned and characterized a mouse orthologue of human ________ protein as an atypical ___ (named ________)
Subcellular fractionation and antibody-uptake experiments indicate that ________ is indeed a type-I membrane protein, but, unlike other ___ isoforms, lacks an N-terminal extracellular domain
Direct interaction between the cytoplasmic tail of _______ and the Src homology 3 domain of ________ activates _____________________________ in C2C12 cells
This suggests that transmembrane _______, by providing docking sites for the Src homology 3 domain of ________, activates PI 3-kinase by mediating its recruitment to the membrane
_____ binds to the C-terminal SH2 domain of ______________________ and inhibits its enzymatic activity

In this report, we demonstrate the stable association of _________ with _____ in a clathrin-coated vesicle complex, which not only binds to the carboxyl-terminal SH2 domain of _________, but also inhibits its enzymatic activity in a dose-dependent manner
Here we demonstrate colocalization and direct interaction between ________ and ____

Overexpression of ________ results in a zinc finger-dependent localization of a ____________ isoform and dynactin to MT bundles, raising the possibility that ________ and ____ regulate dynein/dynactin binding to MTs
This work suggests that ____ is a regulated adapter between ________ and cytoplasmic dynein at sites involved in cargo-MT loading, and/or in the control of MT dynamics
_______ and _______: multifunctional endocytic receptors
_______ and _______ are two structurally different endocytic receptors that interact to serve such functions
_______ and _______ are ____/cyclinB1 kinase inhibitors with a role in S and G2/M cell cycle checkpoints induced by genotoxic stress

_______ (______), _______ (______), and _______ (___) constitute a family of evolutionarily conserved, small, acidic, nuclear proteins, which have been implicated in terminal differentiation, growth suppression, and apoptosis
Recent evidence has implicated _______ in inhibition of ____/cyclinB1 kinase and in G2/M cell cycle arrest
Yet, whether _______ and/or _______ function as inhibitors of ____/cyclinB1 kinase and/or play a role in G2/M cell cycle arrest has not been fully established
In this work, we show that _______ and _______ specifically interact with the ____/CyclinB1 complex, but not with other Cdk/Cyclin complexes, in vitro and in vivo
Data also has been obtained that _______ and _______, as well as _______, interact with both ____ and cyclinB1, resulting in inhibition of the kinase activity of the ____/cyclinB1 complex
Inhibition of ____/cyclinB1 kinase activity by _______ and _______ was found to involve disruption of the complex, whereas _______ did not disrupt the complex
The __________________________________________ ____, also known as _____, is expressed predominantly in epithelial cells, in a variety of tumor cell lines, and in lymphocytes
____ also interacted with other members of the catenin gene family including ____________ and gamma-catenin
The interaction with _________ is likely to be direct, as the interaction occurs in K562 cells lacking functional adherens junctions and __________ expression

Catalytic domains of the tyrosine phosphatases ________, ____, and PTPbeta did not interact with proteins of the catenin family to detectable levels, suggesting that the interaction of ____ with these proteins is specific
____/_____________________________________ ('____')-binding protein (CBP) modulates co-operation between myocyte enhancer factor 2A (_____) and thyroid hormone receptor-retinoid X receptor
____/_____________________________________ ('____')-binding protein (CBP) interacting with transcription factors is able to increase their activity on target gene promoters
Our findings showed that the same C-terminal portion of ____ binds the N-terminal domains of both TR and _____, and our in vivo studies demonstrated that TR, _____ and ____ form a ternary complex
The human ____ and ____ proteins form a ternary complex with hMpp10, which only interacts with the U3 ______ in 60-80S ribonucleoprotein complexes
We have cloned cDNAs encoding the human and mouse homologs of the yeast U3 snoRNP-associated proteins ____ and ____

The results of complementation experiments show that, in contrast to mouse ____, mouse ____ can partially alleviate the growth defect of the corresponding yeast null strain, indicating that the role of ____ in pre-rRNA processing is evolutionarily conserved

The results of density gradient centrifugation experiments show that, in contrast to hU3-55K, the human ____ and ____ proteins predominantly interact with the U3 ______ in 60-80S ribonucleoprotein complexes
In the present study, we observed evidence of cross-talk between the cannabinoid receptor ___ and the _________________ (____) using a heterologous system
In contrast to ____, the potency of direct activation of ___ was not affected by co-expression with ____
In addition, electron microscopy experiments revealed that ___ and ____ are closely apposed at the plasma membrane level; they are close enough to form hetero-oligomers
______, a Rho family _________________________ that interacts with signaling adapters ____ and ____

____ and ____ are scaffolding proteins acting downstream of cell surface receptors and interact with a variety of cytoplasmic signaling proteins such as ____, _____, _____________________________, Shc, and Crk
In addition, ______ contains several classic proline-rich motifs, and it interacts with the first SH3 domain of Crk and full-length ___ in vitro

We propose that ____ and ____ in cooperation with other adapter molecules might regulate the cellular localization of ______ under specific stimuli, acting to regulate precisely Rac and _____ activities
This work led to identification of a novel _________________________ (___) for Rho family GTPases
The GAP domain shows high similarity to the recently cloned _____ and displays activity toward RhoA, ____, and _____ in vitro
The protein was named ______ for its ability to interact with ___ proteins and its activity toward Rac and _____
Expression of ______ in 293T cells led to a reduction in active ____ and _____ levels but not RhoA
A role for ____ phosphorylation of ____ in cytokinesis

Here, we characterize the interaction between ____ and ____, show that ____ phosphorylates ____ at conserved S274 and S326 residues in vitro, and present evidence that ____ is also a substrate for ____ in vivo

Downregulation of ____ by RNA interference results in multiple mitotic defects, including multinucleation and cells arrested at the midbody stage, which are rescued by ectopic expression of wild-type ____, but not by ____ with mutations in the ____ phosphorylation sites
These results suggest that ____ phosphorylation of ____ may influence cytokinesis
Specific interaction of ____ and c/EBPbeta leads to the transcriptional activation of the human ________________________________ gene
The sterol-independent regulatory element (SIRE) of the ____________ (____) promoter mediates ____________ (OM)-induced transcription of the ____ gene through a cholesterol-independent pathway
___ orphan receptor functions as negative modulator for _________________ in prostate cancer cells ____
BACKGROUND: Both _________________ (AR) and orphan receptor ___ (___) belong to the steroid nuclear receptor superfamily and are expressed in prostate cancer tissue and cell lines
The interaction between AR and ___ was assessed by _________________________ (___) pull-down assay and mammalian two-hybrid system assay
The protein ____ functions in a multi-subunit E3 ubiquitin ligase that targets the hypoxia-inducible transcription factor __________ for proteasomal degradation during normoxia
We establish that ____ binds to _____________________ (_____), a component of the 19S regulatory complex of the proteasome
_____ associates with the beta-domain of ____ and complexes with ____ and __________ in vivo
Overexpression of _____ promotes degradation of __________ in a pVHL-dependent manner that requires the ATPase domain of _____
Blockade of _____ expression by small interfering RNA (siRNA) causes prolonged degradation kinetics of __________
Several distinct mutations in exon 2 of ___ disrupt binding of ____ to _____
A ____ mutant containing a P154L substitution coimmunoprecipitates with __________, but not _____, and does not promote degradation of __________
Thus, the ability of ____ to degrade __________ depends in part on its interaction with _____ and suggests a new mechanism for __________ stabilization in some ____-deficient tumors
_____/___/memA interacts with _____, ______ and SRrp130 in corneal epithelial cells
Three SR-rich proteins were identified that interact with the C-terminus of Pnn: _____ and ______, known components of spliceosome machinery, and a novel 130-kDa nuclear protein, SRrp130
Modification of de novo DNA methyltransferase 3a (______) by ______ modulates its interaction with histone deacetylases (HDACs) and its capacity to repress transcription

Here we show that ______ interacts with multiple components of the sumoylation machinery, namely the E2 sumo conjugating enzyme ____ and the E3 sumo ligases _____ and __________, all of which are involved in conjugating the small ubiquitin-like modifier polypeptide, ______, to its target proteins
______ is modified by ______ in vivo and in vitro and the region of ______ responsible for interaction maps to the N-terminal regulatory domain
Functionally, sumoylation of ______ disrupts its ability to interact with histone deacetylases (_____/2), but not with another interaction partner, ______
The tyrosine kinase _____ is physically associated with the Type I interferon (___) receptor complex and is rapidly activated during _________ stimulation
____ interaction with _____ phosphatase ties mitogenic signal transduction to cell cycle activation
We show here that _____ phosphatase associates with ____ in somatic mammalian cells and in meiotic frog oocytes
Differential binding of vascular cell-derived proteoglycans (________, ________, _______, and ________) to the beta-amyloid protein of Alzheimer's disease

Previous studies have demonstrated the immunolocalization of ________, a specific ____________________________, to the ____________ protein (A beta)-containing _______ deposits within the walls of blood vessels (i.e., congophilic angiopathy) in Alzheimer's disease (AD) brain

Overall, the results indicate that specific vascular cell-derived ___ differentially interact with A beta, and that the interactions of highest affinity occur between A beta and binding sites on both the core protein and glycosaminoglycan chains of ________

In the present investigation, the differential binding of previously characterized endothelial cell (EC)- and smooth muscle cell (___)-derived ___ to A beta was examined to determine whether the accumulation of A beta in cerebrovascular _______ deposits may be due to its interactions with ________

Pretreatment of AA amyloidotic splenic and liver tissue sections with synthetic A beta (1-28) produced strong immunoreactivity with A beta antibodies at tissue sites enriched in ________ which was partially removed by pretreatment with heparitinase, but not by chondroitin ___ lyase

[35S]-Sulfate labeled proteoglycans (___) derived from cultured ECs and SMCs bound to affinity columns containing A beta (1-28) or (1-40), with virtually no binding to A beta (40-1) (reverse peptide), beta-amyloid precursor protein (410-429), or bovine _____________

Characterization of EC and ___ ___ bound to A beta (1-28) revealed strong binding by ________, weak binding by _______ and ________, two dermatan sulfate proteoglycans, and lack of binding by ________/____, a large chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan

Cross-linking of ____ with the use of the mAb MEM-53 and a polyclonal sheep anti-mouse Ig promoted activation of resting B cells into the G1 phase of the cell cycle as judged by increased expression of the early activation Ag ____, increases in cellular volume, RNA synthesis, and _____ protein levels, and enhanced binding of 7-aminoactinomycin D
However, cytokines, in particular ____ and ____, potentiated the DNA synthesis induced by cross-linking of ____
The human ____ mRNA editing protein is a __________________ showing structural homology to some known mammalian and bacteriophage deoxycytidylate deaminases
The fact that the ____ mRNA editing protein also exists as a _________ has important implications for the mechanism of ____ mRNA editing in humans
Assignment of _____, ____, and Etfa to chromosomes 3, 7, and 13: the mouse homologs of genes responsible for glutaric acidemia type II in human
We used cDNA probes for the _____, ____, and Etfa genes to determine localization of these mouse genes to chromosomes 3, 7, and 13

Subsequent amino acid sequencing revealed many peptides involving __________ cross-linked either to itself or to a variety of other known CE protein components, including ______________, ___________, ______, keratins, members of the small proline-rich superfamily, ________, and unknown proteins related to the ___________ family

Specific glutamines or lysines of __________ were used to cross-link the different proteins, such as glutamines 495 and 496 to ___________, glutamine 288 to keratins, and lysines 468, 485, and 508 and glutamines 465 and 489 for interchain __________ cross-links
A prominent isolate, designated _____/______, specifically interacts with the ___ not only in vivo but also in vitro
_____ is a nuclear protein with a characteristic distribution in large irregularly shaped nuclear speckles and co-localizes perfectly with the SR domain-containing ____________________
Transient expression of the full-length ____ without RSRS in U1240MG glioblastoma cells resulted in repression of _______ promoter activity
These results suggest that the relative abundance of the two splice variants of ____ in brain could be an important determinant for the expression of _____
